oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Billy Joe Royal Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Billy Joe Royal (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Billy Joe Royal; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Billy Joe Royal and Biff Collie joke about Royal being a disc jockey and "Tell it Like it is" is discussed as a last second recording for Royal; Royal expresses stress from song writers -- (01:48) "Kiss and Say Goodbye" is told by Royal as a heavily requested song consistently -- (02:59) Royal talks about his fears during his first record and discusses the previous recording processes -- (03:59) Royal reflects on the production process that is performed in order to craft a song and scratch tracks is discussed by Royal and Collie -- (05:56) Royal talks about a song written by Ron Reynolds Collie refers to as the "Snake song" [Believed to be "Slip Away"] -- (06:19) Royal talks about Ron Reynolds engineering abilities -- (06:54) Collie and Royal reflect on Reynolds influence on a track -- (07:30) Royal tells of "Cross My Heart and Hope to Try" creativity -- (07:59) Royal and Collie reflect on Bill Lowery as Royal recalls listening to him on WGST -- (09:18) Royal talks about working at a bowling alley and assisting Lowery -- (09:57) Royal reflects on the number of people that rely on him; Collie brings the thought of public view into the conversation -- (11:11) Royal tells of the first time he got writing credits from "Love Has No Right" and Royal reflects on working with Sam Cooke -- (12:25) Royal reflects on the second time meeting Cooke and receiving his praise -- (13:05) Royal reflects on a track [believed to be "Slip Away"] as a song that came together post-demo -- (13:26) Royal thoughts on the production of an unknown track is isolated around the vocals -- (14:13) Royal reflects on the need for compartmentalizing work on a song -- (14:33) "Till I Can't Take it Anymore" is briefly discussed -- (14:49) "I Was Losing You" writer Bruce Burch is praised by Royal and Collie asks Royal about what Burch brought to the song -- (15:38) "What's the Matter Baby" is discussed by Royal as a track that took over five years to cut -- (16:31) "Love Is a Full Time Job" is briefly talked about and Royal and Collie discuss how often songs are changed in a record -- (17:33) Royal tells of how the album was originally supposed to be twenty songs -- (18:03) Collie and Royal reflect on having an abundance of songs [Incomplete]
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Royal, Billy Joe; Collie, Biff;
